completion: Oh, you love getting up early? That's great! I always thought the best part of the day was staring into the abyss of my coffee cup at 6 a.m.
You’re really into meal prepping now? That’s amazing! I, too, love the thrill of eating the same bland chicken and broccoli five days in a row. Keeps life exciting!
Wow, you read a whole book in one sitting? Impressive. I prefer to read half a chapter before I start scrolling through my phone like it's the Holy Grail of procrastination.
Oh, you gave up sugar? That’s awesome! I’ve always wanted to experience life in its raw, unflavored form. Must be thrilling.
You organize your closet by color? Incredible! I find that I get the same result by shoving everything into a pile and hoping for the best.
Wow, you journal every day? That’s so inspiring! I mean, why talk about your feelings when you can just write them down and shove them into a drawer like the rest of us?
You took a social media break? Wow, you’re so strong! I’ve always wanted to not spend hours staring at strangers' vacation photos while sitting on my couch in pajamas.
Oh, you run marathons? Good for you! I love to experience exhaustion and self-doubt after about 20 minutes on the couch.
You meditate every morning? That’s impressive. I tried once, but my brain treated it like a suggestion box at a fast food joint—filled with complaints and bad ideas.
Oh, you only drink green smoothies now? Fantastic! I hear there’s nothing quite like the taste of blended kale to get your day off to a bitter start.
Trump said he’s going to be 'great for women and their reproductive rights.' Well, that’s comforting—like hiring a fox to guard the henhouse, but don’t worry, he’s promised only to take a few eggs.

Kamala Harris gave a speech about lowering grocery prices, and some lawmakers privately told industry officials, 'Don’t worry, this will never pass.' Ah, democracy—where bold ideas die quietly in the back rooms of Congress.

Biden’s son Hunter was convicted of lying about his drug use when purchasing a gun. Finally, something both Republicans and Democrats can agree on If you’re going to break the law, at least be creative about it.

Trump’s rebranding himself as the 'old' candidate, and now suddenly everyone’s concerned about his age. Because apparently, 2024 is the year we realize our presidential candidates have the combined age of ancient Rome.

Biden’s campaign is betting on federal investments in infrastructure, clean energy, and chip manufacturing to create long-term jobs. So, it’s like planting a tree and hoping it grows before your entire lawn catches on fire.
The GOP is fighting over how best to handle immigration, with Trump promising the largest deportation effort in history. Next up: deporting anyone who asks where their Amazon package is coming from.

Trump promised he could end the Russia-Ukraine war in 24 hours if re-elected. Of course, that’s after he finishes his other 24-hour projects, like fixing inflation, cleaning the ocean, and building that wall.

The Supreme Court ruled that presidents can’t be prosecuted for 'official acts.' So, you can do whatever you want as long as you’re sitting behind a big desk and call it 'presidential business.' Perfect, nothing could go wrong.
RFK Jr. just endorsed Trump because, when one conspiracy theorist loses steam, you just join forces with another one. It’s like Voltron for misinformation.
NASA’s astronauts were stuck in space until February because of issues with Boeing’s capsule. But hey, what’s a few extra months in orbit when you can’t get an overbooked flight home anyway?
I went to a meditation retreat to relax, but after three days of forced silence, I left more stressed than when I came in.
My friend started a diet to lose weight. Now he’s more obsessed with food than ever—he talks about cake like it’s an old lover he can’t get over.
I bought a new smartwatch to motivate me to exercise. It’s been two weeks, and it only tracks my excuses.
My cousin went to therapy to work on his anger issues. Now, he just gets mad about how expensive therapy is.
I told my cat not to sit on the keyboard, so naturally, it’s now the only place she’ll sit. Guess I should’ve told her to stay off the couch instead.
I ordered a book on time management, but it took two weeks to arrive because I kept putting off ordering it.
I signed up for a ‘declutter your life’ seminar. Now I just have a new pile of pamphlets and stress about being organized.
I bought a fancy water bottle to help me stay hydrated, but I keep forgetting to fill it. So now it’s just a $30 paperweight.
My brother went on a silent retreat to find inner peace, but when he came back, all he could talk about was how much he hates being quiet.
I got a library card to save money on books, but now I’m spending more on late fees than I ever did on new books.
I used to be a baker, but I couldn’t make enough dough.
I’m reading a book on anti-gravity—it’s impossible to put down.
I was going to tell you a joke about an elevator, but it’s an uplifting experience.
I went to a seafood disco last night and pulled a mussel.
The mathematician couldn’t stop making puns because he was in his prime.
I wanted to be a doctor, but I didn’t have the patients.
I used to be afraid of hurdles, but I got over it.
The kleptomaniac couldn’t help himself—he just took everything for granite.
I was going to make a belt out of watches, but it was a waist of time.
I tried to catch some fog, but I mist.
I used to be a baker, but I couldn’t make enough dough.
I told my carpenter friend he nailed it. He said, 'I always do.'
The new chef at the restaurant is great, but he really knows how to beat an egg.
I was wondering why the baseball was getting bigger, and then it hit me.
I told my friend he should try to pick up golfing. He said, 'I’m more interested in picking up birdies.'
I’ve been reading a book on anti-gravity. It’s impossible to put down.
The electrician offered to give me a shockingly good deal.
She said her relationship was getting stale, so I suggested a little role play. She said, 'As what, a loaf of bread?'
The new gym instructor told me to go hard or go home. I told him I was already hard from the workout.
The gardener asked if I liked his trimming. I said, 'It’s a cut above the rest\!'
Isn’t it funny how we all have that one chair in our house that’s not for sitting? It’s for clothes—clean, dirty, doesn’t matter, it’s just where clothes go to think about their future.

I love how we all have that one junk drawer in the kitchen. You open it, and it’s just random batteries, expired coupons, and a single screw that belongs to nothing—but somehow you’re convinced it’s important.
I don’t get why people ask if you’re ready when they pick you up. Like, if I were ready, I’d be outside by now. Asking just adds five more minutes to the process.

Have you noticed that going to the grocery store for 'just a few things' is a lie we tell ourselves? I always end up with a cart full of snacks I never intended to buy, and somehow I forget the one thing I actually needed.
Why do we all keep old phone chargers that don’t fit any of our devices? It’s like we’re preparing for the day we time travel back to 2010 and need to charge a Blackberry.
Isn’t it weird that we apologize when someone else bumps into us? Like, sorry for existing in this space where I’ve been standing the whole time.

Have you ever tried to keep up with new slang? It’s like trying to learn a whole new language just to understand what the kids are saying on TikTok, but by the time you figure it out, they’ve moved on.

Why is it that when the waiter asks if everything is okay, we always say ‘Yes,’ even if we’ve just been served a disaster on a plate? It’s like we’d rather suffer in silence than risk confrontation over soggy fries.

Isn’t it funny how we all have those reusable grocery bags but always forget to bring them? So now we just have a collection of them, sitting there, waiting for the day we finally remember to take them with us.

Why do we all get embarrassed when our stomach growls in a quiet room? Like, sorry everyone, I’m just a human who hasn’t eaten in three hours—didn’t mean to interrupt your silence with my digestive needs.
I told my therapist I was having trouble sleeping. She suggested counting sheep, but now I’m just lying awake wondering where they go when I stop counting.
I got a new electric toothbrush. It’s so powerful, I’m unsure if I’m cleaning my teeth or polishing them for my casket.
I wanted to join a gym, but I realized lifting my existential dread every morning is probably enough of a workout.
I got a life insurance policy the other day. Nothing like knowing someone will make money off me finally getting some rest.
My friend asked if I wanted to go skydiving. I said, ‘Why? I’m already free-falling through life.’
I ordered a salad because I thought it would make me feel healthier. Turns out, all it did was make me feel like I’m preparing for death by boredom.
People say you only live once, but with the way I sleep, I’m already working on my second life.
I signed up for a cooking class, but I’m not sure it’ll help. Every time I try to cook, it looks less like a meal and more like an autopsy report waiting to happen.
They say laughter is the best medicine, which is probably why my doctor keeps telling me I’m incurable.
I was told to follow my dreams, but at this point, all I’m following is a slow descent into chaos and Netflix binges.
I’m on a new fitness plan. It’s called ‘walking to the fridge and back.’ I’m already a pro.
I tried meal prepping, but I ended up just prepping a week’s worth of regret.
I bought a planner to get more organized. Now I just use it to keep track of all the days I didn’t do anything productive.
My bank account and I have a great relationship. It keeps leaving, and I keep chasing after it like it’s a bad ex.
I went to a yoga class to relax, but by the time I figured out how to fold myself in half, I needed a chiropractor.
I was going to cook a fancy dinner, but then I remembered that I’m the type of person who burns toast—so, takeout it is.
I decided to try meditation. It’s going well, except I keep thinking about snacks during my ‘calm, mindful breathing.’
I told myself I’d get in shape this year, but apparently, the only shape my body is interested in is ‘round.’
I’m really good at multitasking—I can procrastinate and be anxious about it all at the same time.
I tried being an adult, but I accidentally ordered pizza three nights in a row. So, now I’m just aiming for ‘functioning human.’
A man confidently walks into a room, slips on a banana peel, flips into the air, and lands in a perfectly placed pie on the floor.
A woman tries to swat a fly, but with every swing, she knocks over more objects—a lamp, a vase, a chair—until the room is in complete chaos. The fly, of course, is perfectly fine.
A man tries to balance a tall stack of books. He wobbles left, then right, and eventually, the whole stack collapses, sending books flying in every direction.
A woman attempts to sit in a chair, but as she lowers herself, the chair suddenly rolls away. She lands on the floor with a thud, bewildered but unharmed.
Two people carry a long ladder horizontally through a crowded street. As they turn a corner, they accidentally knock over everything in their path—tables, signs, and a few unlucky pedestrians.
A waiter carrying a tray of drinks dramatically slips on a wet floor. In an exaggerated slow-motion sequence, the drinks launch into the air and splatter across the entire room.
A man tries to catch a falling stack of dishes, juggles them in the air, and just when it looks like he might save them, they all crash to the floor in a spectacular mess.
A woman opens a closet door, and an avalanche of junk pours out, completely burying her under a pile of clothes, shoes, and random household items.
A man enthusiastically swings a golf club, but instead of hitting the ball, he spins around and lands face-first in the sand trap.
Two characters pull on opposite ends of a rope, tugging furiously. Suddenly, the rope snaps, sending both flying backward—one into a bush, the other into a conveniently placed puddle.

I’ve been working from home for so long that my Zoom calls now include dramatic background music and slow-motion replays of me getting up to grab a snack—like some kind of overly dramatic sports commentary.
I tried to cook like Gordon Ramsay once. After yelling at my vegetables for five minutes and calling my oven a 'disgrace,' I ended up burning the meal and ordering takeout.

I attempted yoga after watching a YouTube tutorial. Instead of finding inner peace, I found myself stuck in ‘Downward Dog,’ looking like a tangled pretzel, while the instructor kept saying, ‘Just breathe.’ Yeah, right.
My workout playlist is a parody of a motivational speech. It’s like, ‘You can do it! Just one more rep!’ Meanwhile, I’m sitting there, breathless after tying my shoes.
I decided to try being a minimalist, but I took it too far. Now I own one chair, one fork, and a single pair of socks. It’s like living in an Ikea showroom—except with less comfort.
I watched one episode of *The Crown,* and now I demand to be addressed as 'Your Majesty' whenever I enter the room. Sadly, my dog is the only one who listens.
I went to a wine-tasting event and pretended to know what I was doing. ‘Mmm, yes, I detect a hint of grape… and maybe some… fermented grape?’ The sommelier was not amused.
I binge-watched *The Great British Bake Off*, so I tried baking. Now my kitchen looks like a flour bomb exploded, and my cake? Let’s just say it’s more ‘Great British Burn-Off.’

After watching *Top Gun*, I started narrating my daily life like an action movie. ‘He’s making a dangerous left turn into oncoming traffic… Will he survive? Only time will tell.’ Spoiler: I was just going to the grocery store.
I attempted to Marie Kondo my closet. The only thing that sparked joy was finding my old band T-shirts, but now I have a more emotional attachment to my junk than ever before.

I love how we have 24-hour news channels to keep us informed. Now I can spend my entire day getting the same three facts repeated with increasingly dramatic music, just in case I didn’t understand it the first 20 times.
Ah, nothing like a diet commercial reminding me that my worth is tied to my waistline. Because obviously, happiness and success only come in a size small.

It's great that billionaires are going to space now. I mean, when you've already got ten mansions, two yachts, and an island, where else is there to go but off the planet? Earth is just so last season.

I really appreciate how social media algorithms only show me what I already agree with. It's like living in a cozy little bubble where my opinions are always right—so refreshing not having to think critically about anything anymore.
Isn't it amazing how companies 'go green' by slapping a leaf on the label? Because we all know that a drawing of a tree on my plastic water bottle really helps reduce pollution.

I love how the education system prepares us for life by making sure we know the Pythagorean theorem. Because when I’m stressed about paying rent, it’s a huge relief to know how to find the hypotenuse of a triangle.
I really admire how modern fashion is all about looking effortlessly chic. Because nothing says 'effortless' like spending three hours and half a paycheck to look like you just rolled out of bed.
It's comforting to know that in times of crisis, politicians are quick to tweet their thoughts and prayers. Truly, nothing solves global issues faster than a hashtag and a sad face emoji.

I just love voting season. It’s that special time of year when politicians pretend to care about me for exactly as long as it takes to get my vote. After that, it’s back to being an extra in their democracy drama.

I think it's wonderful how insurance companies are here to help—by making sure I pay a monthly fee just in case something happens. But if something does happen, they’re right there with a kind 'Sorry, not covered' response.

I tried to fix the sink last weekend. You know, how hard can it be, right? Well, now I’m on a first-name basis with the plumber and my kitchen floor feels like the aftermath of SeaWorld’s splash zone.

I recently started a 'beginner's' yoga class. By 'beginner,' they clearly meant 'people who can already bend in half.' Meanwhile, I’m over here trying to touch my toes like it's some kind of magic trick.
So, I decided to bake cookies for the first time in years. Followed the recipe to a T, but apparently my oven was auditioning for *Hell's Kitchen*, because what came out could double as hockey pucks.
Last week, I went for a run—felt great until I realized I had only made it to the end of my driveway. I guess my body’s idea of 'exercise' is walking to the fridge and back.

I tried to be productive and clean out my closet. Three hours later, I was sitting on the floor surrounded by clothes I didn’t even remember buying, and I still managed to put half of it back. Progress, right?
I joined a book club to seem cultured. Turns out, the only thing I’m really good at discussing is how long the wine lasts between chapters.
I decided to cook dinner for a change, instead of ordering takeout. Halfway through, I realized I forgot to buy half the ingredients, so I improvised. My dog seemed to love it—my family, not so much.

I went on a hike the other day—well, more like a glorified walk through the woods. I was proud until a family of toddlers and a grandmother power-walked past me. So, I stopped to 'enjoy the view'—a.k.a. catch my breath.

I once tried to follow one of those 30-day fitness challenges. By day three, I was challenging myself to find creative ways to skip the workout without feeling guilty. 'Does walking to the car count? What if I take the stairs once?' It’s all about balance!

I recently started meal prepping—planned out a whole week’s worth of healthy meals. By day two, I was trading my grilled chicken for pizza and convincing myself that the calories don’t count if you eat it standing up.
I’m so tired, I could sleep for a century and still wake up cranky.
My inbox has so many unread emails, I’m pretty sure I’ll need a treasure map to find the bottom of it.
The line at the coffee shop was so long, I had time to learn a new language, forget it, and relearn it.
I’m so hungry, I could eat an entire buffet and still have room for dessert.
My dog sheds so much fur, I could knit an entire wardrobe out of it and still have enough left over for a blanket.
I ate so much at dinner, I think I’ve single-handedly delayed the restaurant’s food supply chain for a week.
The Wi-Fi was so slow, I felt like I was trying to load a webpage using smoke signals.
I was stuck in traffic so long, I had enough time to contemplate the meaning of life, solve world peace, and still not move an inch.
It’s so hot outside, I’m pretty sure my shoes melted to the sidewalk.
My phone battery dies so fast, I’m surprised it doesn’t come with a pre-written goodbye note.
I went to the hardware store to pick up a hammer, but I ended up needing a bigger tool to get the job done.
I tried baking a pie, but the filling kept spilling out—guess I overstuffed it.
He said he could fix my pipes, but after he was done, I still felt like something was leaking.
She said she’s really good with plants… I’m just hoping she can keep mine well-watered and thriving.
I took a yoga class to get more flexible… let’s just say I can now reach places I didn’t even know existed.
I ordered a footlong sandwich, and trust me, it was more than I could handle.
They told me the package was oversized, but I managed to fit it in just fine.
I asked him to help me move some heavy furniture, but after all that lifting, we both needed a break.
I finally bought a new car, and let’s just say, it’s got more power under the hood than I know what to do with.
She invited me over to help decorate her place, but somehow we ended up rearranging more than just the furniture.
I’m really into minimalism. That’s why I own nothing… except crippling debt.
I tried running today. Didn’t go well. So now I’m just walking… back to bed.
People keep telling me I look tired. That’s weird, because I’m actually exhausted.
I bought a self-help book. Now I’m just waiting for it to help itself to the trash.
I started meditating. It’s really calming, except for all the thoughts that won’t stop screaming.
I think my phone hates me. It keeps dying just to avoid talking to me.
I’m on a diet. It’s called the ‘see food’ diet. I see food, and I eat it.
My doctor told me to get more exercise, so now I walk to the fridge twice before getting the ice cream.
I’ve decided to be more positive. I’m positively sure that everything is a disaster.
I tried yoga. It was going well until I fell asleep in child’s pose.
I tried to teach my cat how to juggle, but he just stared at me like I was the one who didn’t understand gravity.
I went to the store to buy milk, but somehow I came home with a duck in a raincoat and a can of invisible beans.
I once tried to cook pasta, but it ran away before I could catch it. Now I’m stuck eating cereal that won’t stop whispering my secrets.
I put my shoes on the wrong feet today. It wouldn’t have been a problem if they didn’t start arguing about who was doing a better job.
The last time I tried to be productive, my to-do list grew arms and legs, then ran off to join the circus. Haven’t seen it since.
I asked my dog why he barks at the mailman, and he told me it’s because the moon won’t stop stealing his socks.
I once had a goldfish that could do algebra. But then it got distracted by the quadratic formula and left for a life of existential pondering.
I went to a restaurant where they serve breakfast all day, but when I ordered pancakes at 6 p.m., they just handed me a clock and told me to wait.
My plants have started a book club. I’m not allowed to join, but they leave notes like, ‘Water us or else.’ It’s very tense.
I thought I saw a UFO yesterday, but it turned out to be a giant frisbee thrown by a very ambitious squirrel.
Why did the toilet paper roll down the hill? To get to the bottom of things.
I tried to sneak a fart in class, but it ended up sounding like a trumpet solo. I guess I’m not cut out for silent but deadly missions.
I asked my friend what’s brown and sticky. He said, ‘A stick.’ I said, ‘Nope, that’s just what happens after you eat a bad burrito.’
I went to the bathroom at a fancy restaurant, and the toilet flushed itself. I guess even toilets here have better manners than I do.
My dog farted and looked at me like I did it. I’m like, ‘Buddy, we both know who’s eating the mystery kibble around here.’
Why do farts always seem louder in public bathrooms? It’s like the echo adds five decibels to the embarrassment.
I dropped my phone in the toilet once. Now every time I use it, I wonder if it’s still holding a grudge.
If poop jokes aren’t your thing, I totally understand. But come on, they’re pretty solid, right?
I tried to hold in a sneeze, but instead, I ended up farting. Great, now my body’s just improvising.
Ever notice how the more you try not to laugh at a fart, the funnier it gets? It’s like farts have some kind of hidden comedic timing superpower.
I love waking up early. Nothing like starting my day with a headache and a bad attitude to get things rolling.
Oh, you don’t like chocolate? That’s amazing—what’s it like being completely devoid of joy and happiness?
I’m so bad at math, I could probably subtract three from five and somehow end up in a different time zone.
Sure, I’ll just do the dishes for the millionth time this week. I’m a professional dishwasher now—thinking of adding it to my résumé.
I went to the gym once and immediately gained superhuman strength. Now I can lift a bag of chips without breaking a sweat.
I’d love to attend your four-hour meeting about nothing. It’s like a dream come true—who needs free time or happiness anyway?
I’m so great at multitasking, I can worry about my entire life falling apart while doing absolutely nothing about it.
Wow, you’re doing yoga? That’s so impressive! Next, you’ll probably be able to levitate or achieve eternal enlightenment—totally within reach.
Sure, I’ll help you move. Nothing I love more than lifting heavy furniture and questioning all of my life choices at the same time.
I love Mondays so much; I think I’ll petition to have them twice a week—because who doesn’t want double the exhaustion and existential dread?
I love working late. Nothing says ‘I value my time’ like spending it all on something I couldn’t care less about.
The best part of adulting is paying bills. Nothing more satisfying than watching your hard-earned money disappear into the void.
It’s great that we have social media now. I really needed a place where I can pretend to care about what people I haven’t seen in 10 years are doing with their lives.
I went to the doctor, and they told me I should exercise more. I guess slowly dying from inactivity wasn’t the workout plan they had in mind.
I’m so glad I spent years in school, so I could enter the workforce and realize that nothing I learned actually matters.
I finally cleaned my house today. Now it’s spotless, and I can enjoy the five seconds of peace before life comes in and wrecks everything again.
I tried to eat healthy for a week. Now I’m just waiting for my award for enduring the sheer misery of salads and tasteless vegetables.
Oh, you’re getting married? That’s great. I hear signing up for a lifelong roommate is exactly what every introvert dreams of.
I love going to the gym. Nothing like paying money to feel bad about how out of shape you are in front of strangers.
I tried meditation to reduce my stress. Turns out, the real stress relief comes from realizing that nothing actually matters.

I was at the grocery store, and my phone rang. It was my mom asking if I needed anything. I said, 'I’m at the store, Mom.' She says, 'Okay, but do you need anything?' I said, 'Yes, patience. Lots of it.'

I went to the dentist, and they said, 'Have you been flossing?' I lied and said, 'Yes, of course.' Then they handed me the floss like it was some rare artifact, and I had to pretend I wasn’t baffled by it.

I tried to look cool at the gym by lifting heavier weights. Thirty seconds later, I was trapped under the barbell, trying to figure out if I could use my phone to call for help without anyone noticing.
I was at a restaurant, and the waiter asked how my food was. I said, 'It’s great!' Then I went back to chewing the world’s driest chicken like it was a personal challenge not to choke.
My friend told me they never get sick. So, naturally, the next day, they’re laid out with a cold, and I had to resist the urge to show up with a 'Congratulations, you’re human' card.
I tried to be polite and hold the door for someone, but they were so far away that I ended up standing there for an eternity, slowly regretting every life choice that led me to this moment.
I went to a party, and someone asked if I had any hobbies. I panicked and said, 'I like sleeping.' They laughed, but little did they know, I was dead serious.

I once tried to tell a joke at a party, but I got so nervous halfway through that I completely forgot the punchline. So, naturally, I just ended with, 'And then we all died…' Surprisingly, everyone laughed.

I was on a video call, and my cat decided that was the perfect time to walk across the keyboard. I tried to play it off like, 'Oh, she’s helping with the meeting,' but in reality, she was just trying to sabotage my career.
I went to make a quick phone call and accidentally dialed my ex. Instead of hanging up, I panicked and left a message pretending to be the cable company offering a new bundle.
Amazon is helping the Israeli military store surveillance data. Wow, next-day shipping and surveillance—talk about customer service!
The U.N. says we’re not seeing the money needed for climate justice. Even saving the planet is on backorder—maybe they should try Prime.
They just disbanded Thailand’s largest opposition party for criticizing the royal family. Well, that’s one way to avoid bad Yelp reviews.
Bangladesh is on its 'second liberation day,' but given the political climate, they may consider doing a third and fourth just to be safe.
Mpox is spreading, and now they’re warning us not to have sex if we’ve got lesions. Well, that’s one way to kill the mood—'Hey baby, mind if I just… not?'
Sudan’s got famine, and the U.N. says it's a 'shameful stain on our collective conscience.' Well, if conscience-cleaning were a job, I’d say we’ve got a full-blown laundry emergency.
Schools in Gaza are being bombed, and chlorine is running out. Meanwhile, I’m getting upset when Starbucks runs out of oat milk. Perspective, right?
With extreme heat causing a national blood shortage, maybe it’s time to start considering iced blood donations—keep it cool, people.
Kamala Harris is being defended as tough on crime. In other news, I defended my cat as 'tough on laziness'—neither statement went over well.
Cori Bush lost her primary after AIPAC dropped $9 million to defeat her. At this point, maybe they should just start sending politicians those 'We’ll pay you to leave' gift baskets.
I went to a nude beach once. Let’s just say some things are better left to the imagination—like the sight of that guy playing volleyball.
They say marriage is about compromise. That’s why we have two bathrooms—one for me and one for whatever science experiment my husband’s got going on after taco night.
I tried to talk dirty to my partner, but we just ended up laughing because I sounded like I was narrating a cooking show.
Ever sneeze in public and accidentally let out something else? Yeah, that’s when you just keep walking and hope nobody noticed… even though they definitely did.
I love romance. Nothing says 'I love you' like spending 20 minutes trying to find a comfortable position that doesn’t involve elbowing each other in the ribs.
I tried to give my partner a back rub to be sexy, but I’m pretty sure I just dislocated a shoulder.
The difference between men and women? When a guy says he’s 'ready,' it usually means his pants are still on the floor somewhere.
I joined a gym to work on my glutes, but it turns out the only thing getting a workout is the amount of time I spend trying to look like I know what I’m doing.
Getting older is fun. My body’s starting to make noises I didn’t even know were possible. I bend down, and suddenly I’m a symphony of creaks and pops.
Sex in movies is all passionate and glamorous. In real life, it’s more like, 'Wait, was that your elbow or my knee? Never mind, just keep going.'
Politicians are like diapers—they need to be changed often, and for the same reason.
I love how every election is about ‘change.’ Four years later, we’re all like, ‘Wow, everything’s exactly the same, but now with more campaign ads.’
They say politicians work for the people. Sure, but only if 'the people' is code for lobbyists and major donors.
I went to a political rally once. It was like a rock concert, except instead of good music, they just played the greatest hits of broken promises.
Campaign promises are amazing—it's like watching a magician pull rabbits out of hats, except the rabbits disappear as soon as they win.
They say voting is important because every vote counts. Unless it’s in the electoral college—then it’s like, ‘Eh, we’ll figure it out for you.’
I wish I had the confidence of a politician. They can mess up an entire country and still ask for a raise.
In politics, it’s all about spin. If politicians spun any faster, they’d start generating renewable energy.
Congress is like a group project where everyone hates each other, nobody does their part, and somehow you still get an F.
I love how politicians say they 'work across the aisle.' Yeah, they’re crossing the aisle to grab a snack and then heading back to gridlock.
I tried to teach my goldfish how to play the piano, but he just kept swimming in circles. Turns out, he prefers jazz.
I opened my fridge, and inside was a tiny giraffe making toast. I didn’t question it—I just asked him to pass the butter.
I went to the dentist, but instead of a check-up, they handed me a shovel and told me to dig for my teeth in the backyard. Surprisingly, I found a treasure chest.
My alarm clock didn’t go off this morning. Instead, it turned into a bird, flew out the window, and squawked, ‘You’re late!’ as it disappeared into the sunrise.
I walked into the bookstore, and every book was upside down and written in ancient runes. The cashier was a cat wearing glasses, but he gave me a discount, so I didn’t mind.
I ordered a salad at a restaurant, but when it arrived, it was a bouquet with a tiny note that said, ‘Eat dreams, not leaves.’ So I tipped the waiter in Monopoly money.
I went for a jog this morning, but halfway through, the pavement turned into marshmallows, and suddenly I was bouncing down the street like an astronaut on a trampoline.
I looked up at the night sky and saw that the moon had become a giant cookie. Naturally, I grabbed a ladder and tried to take a bite, but the stars told me it was gluten-free.
My car refused to start, so I asked it nicely. It responded by turning into a bicycle and saying, ‘Let’s pedal our way to enlightenment.’ So I grabbed my helmet and followed its lead.
I sat down to write a letter, but the pen turned into a snake and started telling me jokes. We ended up writing a comedy sketch together—it was hiss-terical.

Here we have the elusive office worker, seen in its natural habitat: staring blankly at a screen while pretending to be busy. Notice how it expertly navigates the art of looking productive during a two-hour scroll through social media.

In a rare sighting, we observe the suburban dad attempting to assemble a barbecue grill without instructions. Watch as he bravely pretends he knows what he's doing, despite the growing pile of extra screws.

This is the story of the modern shopper. Notice how they enter the grocery store with a list of essentials but quickly abandon all logic and load their cart with snacks, candles, and a set of kitchen utensils they'll never use.
Meet Sarah, a seasoned remote worker. Watch as she masterfully switches between work emails and Netflix in the blink of an eye, a skill honed over years of ‘multitasking’ from the comfort of her bed.

We follow the rare phenomenon known as ‘cleaning the house for guests.’ Witness as the subject frantically stuffs clutter into random closets, creating a false sense of order, only to forget where they hid everything later.

This is Bob, a seasoned driver stuck in morning traffic. Observe his complete lack of reaction as he listens to the same radio show he's heard for years, slowly losing his will to care about the latest ‘breaking news.’

In the wild, we see the urban hipster in their favorite environment—a local coffee shop. Here, they order drinks with names so complex, it’s hard to tell if they’re asking for a beverage or reciting poetry.

Today, we document the mysterious behavior of the cat owner. Watch as they attempt to get their cat’s attention, only to be met with cold indifference. And yet, they will continue to try, undeterred by years of rejection.

In this rare moment, we capture the weekend warrior as they enthusiastically plan a hike. Little do they know, their adventure will end not on a mountaintop, but on the couch, with snacks and a movie marathon.

We observe the millennial in their natural habitat: the streaming service menu. Watch as they spend hours scrolling through options, only to select the same comfort show they’ve watched ten times before.
Arnold Schwarzenegger: I’ll be back... after I find where I left my car keys. They’re around here somewhere. Hasta la vista, clutter\!
David Attenborough: And here we see the rare human, venturing into the grocery store without a list, wandering aimlessly, lost in its natural habitat… the snack aisle.
Gordon Ramsay: This chicken is so undercooked, it just flew off the plate and tried to file for birdseed\!
Yoda: To the fridge, I go. Snacks, I must have. Hungry, I am.
Morgan Freeman: I walked into that room, and I knew instantly… that I’d forgotten why I’d gone in there. But sometimes, it’s not about the destination. It’s about the journey back to the couch.
Christopher Walken: Wow\! You’ve got to stop… eating all the cookies. Leave some… for the rest of us. I mean… come on\!
Robert De Niro: You talkin’ to me? You talkin’ to me? No really, are you talking to me, or are you on your Bluetooth? I can never tell these days.
Elvis Presley: Thank you, thank you very much… but I can’t fit into these blue suede shoes anymore after all that peanut butter and banana.

Matthew McConaughey: Alright, alright, alright. Life’s like a highway, man. You just gotta cruise. But sometimes, you hit a traffic jam, and then you just gotta chill. Be cool, like a cucumber on a summer day.
Sylvester Stallone (Rocky Balboa): Yo, Adrian\! I did it\! I folded the laundry... well, almost. There’s still a sock missing, but it’s out there. Somewhere.

The Overly Enthusiastic Tour Guide: And here we have the breakroom—where dreams come to die\! I mean, recharge\! Isn’t it exciting? Look at that microwave—it’s been defrosting frozen lunches since 1998\! Amazing, right?

The Relentlessly Optimistic Waiter: Oh, your soup is cold? That’s just how we serve it here, it’s, um, artisanal\! A real culinary experience\! You get the full flavor profile when you don’t let the heat distract you\!

The Conspiracy Theory Neighbor: You see, the government’s been hiding the truth from us for years. That’s why your Wi-Fi keeps cutting out—aliens\! And the squirrels? Don’t trust ‘em. They’re spies, man. Wake up\!

The Eccentric Artist: This sculpture? Oh, darling, it’s an expression of my inner turmoil, a reflection of society’s downfall, and, yes, it’s made entirely out of spaghetti noodles. Art is pain, you know?

The Paranoid IT Guy: Oh, you want to open that email? Are you sure? Because that’s exactly what they want you to do. One click, and boom—you’ve opened the gateway to hackers, viruses, and probably the dark web. Just use a pigeon next time\!
The Overconfident DIY Dad: Why hire a plumber when I can fix it myself? Hand me that duct tape. And that hammer. And… wait, does anyone know how to turn the water off? Never mind, I got this\!
The Superhero with Questionable Powers: Fear not\! I am here to save the day… as long as that day involves finding lost car keys or getting jars open. Anything else might be outside my jurisdiction.

The Inappropriate Office Comedian: Oh, you’re getting married? That’s great\! I’ve been married three times. Let me give you some advice: never argue about who left the toilet seat up—it’s a slippery slope to separate vacations.

The Pretentious Barista: You want just a regular coffee? How quaint. But have you considered our single-origin, handpicked, shade-grown, ethically sourced, cold-brewed, nitrogen-infused espresso? It’s what the gods would drink… if they could afford it.
The Forgetful Grandparent: Back in my day, we didn’t have all this fancy technology. No, we just sent messages through… what was it again? Pigeons? Smoke signals? Anyway, what was I talking about?
He told his friend to 'chill out,' so naturally, he ended up locked in the walk-in freezer for the next half hour.
After bragging that he was a master chef, he ended up with a kitchen full of burnt pans and a smoke alarm that wouldn’t stop blaring. Master chef indeed.
She insisted she didn’t need a map on the hike. Three hours later, they were ‘exploring’ the same patch of forest for the fourth time.
He thought he could impress everyone by showing off his dance moves at the party. Now, he’s known as the guy who slipped on spilled punch and face-planted into the cake.
He joked about being the fastest runner in the group. His 'punishment'? Having to chase after the bus they all left him behind on.
She swore she could build that Ikea bookshelf without the instructions. The punishment? Three hours later, she had an abstract sculpture made of wooden planks and misplaced screws.
He mocked the old printer for being slow. Naturally, it chose the next moment to jam spectacularly and cover him in a flurry of paper.
She insisted she could handle spicy food like a pro. Five minutes into the meal, she was guzzling milk straight from the carton, and her face was redder than the hot sauce.
He refused to use sunblock because he ‘never burns.’ Now he’s spending the rest of the vacation looking like a lobster, and his friends won’t stop calling him 'Red.'
She tried to cut corners on her DIY project, claiming, 'It’ll hold!' Now she’s staring at a broken table that collapsed when someone placed a cup on it.
My friend said she wants to break up with her boyfriend but doesn’t know how. I told her, ‘Just start calling him by your ex’s name—it’ll take care of itself.’
I asked my wife if she loved me, and she said, ‘Of course I do, especially when you're out of the house.’
My boss said I should take more initiative at work. So, I started packing up his office.
I told my friend I’m thinking about getting a dog. She said, ‘Oh good, someone else for you to disappoint.’
I asked my husband what he’d do if I left him. He said, ‘Well, I’d finally get some peace and quiet around here.’
I told my friend I was feeling lonely. She said, ‘You get used to it. Or at least that’s what my plants tell me.’
I told my mom I was stressed, and she said, ‘Well, maybe if you made better choices, you wouldn’t be.’
My therapist told me I needed to let go of the past. So I stopped paying her bills—she’s part of my past now.
I told my partner I wanted to work on our relationship. They said, ‘Great, you can start by working on yourself first.’
I asked my friend how I could improve myself. She said, ‘Well, you could start by being someone else entirely.’
Why did the chicken cross the road? To buy a skateboard because the bananas told him it was the only way to get to Mars.
I went to the store to buy some milk, but I came home with a unicycle and a penguin named Gerald.
What’s the secret to a happy marriage? Always keep a rubber duck in your sock drawer for emergencies.
Knock knock.
Who’s there? Orange. Orange who? Never mind, I’m a toaster.
I asked my teacher for advice on studying. She handed me a spoon and told me to always trust a giraffe in a hat.
Why don’t elephants use computers? Because it’s impossible to juggle spaghetti underwater on a Tuesday.
I tried going to the gym, but instead I ended up learning how to speak fluent alpaca.
My friend asked if I wanted to go for a walk, so naturally, I handed him a pineapple and started tap dancing.
What do you call a bear with no teeth? It doesn’t matter, because all the furniture in my house is made of marshmallows.
I was feeling sad, so I ate a sandwich. Now the pigeons won’t stop giving me financial advice.
Why did the chicken cross the road? Wait, are we still doing this joke? Hasn’t the chicken crossed the road enough times by now?
Knock knock. Who’s there? It’s me, the part of the joke that explains why this is funny. I’m just here to make sure you know this is all very clever.
This is the part of the joke where you’re supposed to laugh, so I’ll just pause for your convenience.
I was going to make a joke about time travel, but then I realized it’s already been done in the future. So, never mind.
Here’s a funny story… Actually, you know what? I’m just going to skip the setup and tell you it’s funny. We all know where this is going.
I wanted to tell a pun, but then I realized, does the world really need another pun? Isn’t this whole joke just me fulfilling some tired comedic obligation?
A man walks into a bar. Wait, why are men always walking into bars in these jokes? You’d think by now, bars would have installed some kind of doorbell.
This joke is like a trainwreck—you know you should stop reading, but you can’t look away. And now here we are, stuck in this mess together.
I’m about to tell a joke, but first let’s acknowledge how awkward this is for both of us. You’re waiting for the punchline, and I’m pretending I know what I’m doing.
This is a meta-joke. It’s self-aware. It knows it’s a joke, but it also knows it’s tired of being a joke. Maybe it just wants to be taken seriously for once.
I tried to text my boss that I was 'running late,' but autocorrect changed it to 'ruining fate.' Now I’m pretty sure I’m getting a formal written warning… from destiny.
I accidentally waved back at someone who wasn’t waving at me. To make it less awkward, I pretended I was just swatting at an imaginary fly… for a good ten seconds.
I was late to the meeting and tried to sneak in quietly. Of course, the door squeaked like a haunted house, and then I tripped over a chair. Nothing says ‘professional’ like crashing into a room.
I went to an important dinner and confidently ordered in French. The waiter just stared at me and said, ‘Sir, this is an Italian restaurant.’
I called my friend to vent about how annoying my boss is. It turns out that I had accidentally called my boss. Now I’m just waiting for that awkward Monday morning chat.
I thought it would be impressive to parallel park in front of my date. Instead, I hit the curb, bounced onto the sidewalk, and blocked two parking spots. Romantic, right?
I tried to make a good first impression by shaking hands with my new colleague. Instead, I knocked her coffee out of her hand, and we both just stood there staring at the mess.
I proudly told everyone I’d fixed the leaky faucet by myself. Five minutes later, the kitchen was flooding, and my cat was trying to float on a dish towel.
I mistook a stranger for my friend and hugged them from behind. When they turned around, we both just stood there, horrified. I wish the earth had swallowed me whole.
I was trying to look cool on my new bike, but when I tried to stop, my foot missed the pedal, and I crashed straight into a trash can. I just pretended that was the plan all along.
Why did the chicken cross the road? Because chickens can’t operate vehicles.
Knock knock. Who’s there? It’s me. I just wanted to say hello.
What’s brown and sticky? A stick.
Why did the boy drop his ice cream? Because he tripped.
How do you make a tissue dance? You don’t. You just blow your nose into it.
Why can’t dinosaurs talk? Because they’re extinct.
What did one wall say to the other? Nothing. Walls can’t talk.
Why was six afraid of seven? It wasn’t. Numbers are not sentient beings.
What do you call a fish with no eyes? A fish, because it doesn’t need eyes to be a fish.
Why did the man fall down the well? Because he didn’t see the well, and therefore, he fell.
Julius Caesar walked into Starbucks and said, 'Et tu, barista? I ordered a latte, not a cappuccino!'
Shakespeare in a modern classroom: 'To be or not to be… that’s what I’ll Google later.'
King Arthur pulls out his sword and says, 'Is this Excalibur? No, it’s an iPhone! Where did this come from?'
Mozart steps up to a DJ booth and says, 'Forget sonatas, let’s drop some beats!'
Abraham Lincoln scrolling through Twitter: 'Four score and seven notifications ago… wait, why is everyone tagging me in memes?'
Leonardo da Vinci painting the Mona Lisa, suddenly asks, 'Can I get a selfie with her before we finish up?'
Cleopatra takes a selfie with her smartphone and says, 'Let’s send this to Marc Antony, \#QueenOfTheNile.'
Napoleon Bonaparte stood on the battlefield and said, 'I should’ve just played Risk on my Xbox instead of invading Russia.'
Marie Antoinette, at a bakery, asks, 'Do you guys have any gluten-free, vegan cake? Because, you know, let them eat that!'
Albert Einstein sits down in front of his MacBook and says, 'Let me figure out this theory of relativity… right after I finish updating my Instagram.'
They say money can’t buy happiness, but it sure makes misery more comfortable.
I finally found inner peace… it’s called not caring anymore.
Hard work never killed anyone, but why take the risk?
The light at the end of the tunnel? Probably just another oncoming train.
I used to have goals, but now I just hope to get through the day without losing Wi-Fi.
You miss 100% of the shots you don’t take… and most of the ones you do, but hey, why not disappoint yourself both ways?
They say the truth will set you free, but that’s usually after it destroys your life first.
Optimism is just the fancy word people use when they haven’t been disappointed enough yet.
Every cloud has a silver lining, but that’s probably just the toxic chemicals from pollution.
The grass is always greener on the other side because it’s probably artificial turf.
I asked my dog if he wanted to go for a walk, but he said he was too tired. Then I remembered dogs don’t talk.
I wanted to lose weight, so I bought a treadmill. Now I just hang clothes on it.
My boss told me to start thinking outside the box, so I quit my job.
I can resist anything except temptation and, apparently, cheesecake.
I thought I wanted a career. Turns out, I just wanted a steady income.
I used to play piano by ear, but then I learned to use my hands like everyone else.
My memory is so good that I can remember every time I’ve forgotten something important.
I’m reading a book on anti-gravity. It’s impossible to put down—literally, it floats away.
They say practice makes perfect. So, I’m perfect at procrastination.
I always give 100% at work—10% on Monday, 20% on Tuesday, and so on.
I tried to catch some fog this morning. Missed it by a mile—turns out, it evaporates faster than my motivation.
Why did the paper towel go to therapy? It had too many issues to absorb.
I asked my calendar why it was so organized. It said, 'Because I always date my entries.'
What do you call a lazy kangaroo? A pouch potato.
I told my shoes they were untied. They didn’t respond—guess they’re tongue-tied.
Why did the cookie go to the doctor? It was feeling a little crumby.
I tried to open a bakery, but I kept losing dough. Turns out, money can’t buy batter days.
I got a job at a mirror factory. It’s the only place where I can truly reflect on my life.
Why do bees have sticky hair? They use honeycombs, obviously.
I bought a boat because I needed an oar-some way to float through life..
Isn’t it weird how we all have that one drawer in the kitchen full of random things? It’s like the junk drawer is where paper clips, batteries, and forgotten keys go to retire.

You ever notice how people always say, 'I need coffee to wake up,' but they somehow managed to get dressed, drive to Starbucks, and order—all while ‘asleep’? That’s either talent or autopilot at its finest.
Why is it that the moment you’re comfortable in bed, you suddenly remember something you forgot to do? It’s like my brain waits for me to be cozy to remind me I left the oven on.

I love when people say, ‘I’m just going to pop into the store real quick.’ Ten minutes later, they’re coming out with a cart full of stuff they didn’t even know they needed—because who can resist a sale on 50 rolls of paper towels?

Have you ever noticed how a ‘quick’ shower only lasts 20 minutes if you’re running late? But when you have all the time in the world, that shower turns into a full-blown concert and life reflection session.
Why is it that the one day you forget to charge your phone, that’s when everyone suddenly needs to reach you? My phone’s on 5%, and suddenly I’m more popular than a free donut stand.
Have you ever watched people trying to parallel park? It’s like watching someone play Tetris with a car—except, in this game, you only have one piece, and it’s impossible to fit it into the space.
Why do we always get nervous when our phone rings? It’s literally designed for calls, yet every time it rings, it’s like we’ve forgotten how to interact with another human being.
You ever walk into a room and completely forget why you went in? It’s like the doorway is a magic portal that erases all memory of the important thing you were about to do.
Why do we spend so much time picking out the perfect outfit just to sit at home and binge-watch TV? My couch has no opinion on my fashion choices, but here I am, dressed like I’m expecting company.
I wanted to kill two birds with one stone, but PETA wasn’t too thrilled with that idea.
I told my boss I was burning the midnight oil, but he said, ‘We use LED lights now—get with the times.’
I decided to let sleeping dogs lie, but now they’ve taken over the entire bed and I’m stuck on the couch.
They say actions speak louder than words, but when I tried miming my grocery list, nobody understood a thing.
I’ve got bigger fish to fry, but I just realized I don’t even own a frying pan.
I tried to break the ice at the party, but apparently, using a sledgehammer isn’t what they meant.
They told me to bite the bullet, but all I got was a chipped tooth and a stern warning from my dentist.
I heard the early bird gets the worm, so I showed up at dawn—only to find out I’m allergic to worms.
I wanted to take the bull by the horns, but then I remembered I’m a terrible rodeo clown.
They said curiosity killed the cat, so I played it safe and let the cat Google things for me.
So, I went to the gym for the first time in months. I walked in feeling confident, grabbed a set of weights, and instantly dropped them on my foot. I guess that’s what they mean by a ‘hard start.’

The other day, I asked my neighbor for help moving some furniture. He showed up with a tape measure and spent 30 minutes analyzing the best route. By the time we were ready to move it, I had already pushed it across the room myself. So much for ‘teamwork.’

I went to a restaurant and asked for something light, so the waiter brought me a salad. I stared at it and said, ‘No, I meant something like a cheeseburger, but with less guilt.’ He just blinked and brought me a glass of water.

I was babysitting my niece, and she asked me to help with her homework. It was math, so I thought, ‘How hard could it be?’ Ten minutes in, I realized I had no idea what I was doing, and she ended up teaching me. So, technically, I got an education for free.
I tried taking a yoga class. The instructor said, ‘Breathe in peace, breathe out tension.’ But after 10 minutes of trying to touch my toes, I was mostly breathing out regret.

I went camping with some friends, and we set up this huge tent. It looked great until it started raining. Turns out, none of us knew how to properly stake it down. So, we spent the night chasing our tent around the campsite like it was some wild animal.

My car broke down in the middle of nowhere, so I called roadside assistance. The guy on the phone said, ‘Can you describe your location?’ I said, ‘Yeah, it’s somewhere between ‘Why did I take this road?’ and ‘I’m never going on a road trip again.’

I decided to cook dinner for my in-laws to impress them. Halfway through, the smoke alarm went off, and the dog started barking. Let’s just say, we ended up ordering pizza, and they’re probably more impressed with my phone’s delivery app.

I went to the airport three hours early because I’m one of those overly cautious people. Of course, my flight was delayed by four hours, so I spent the entire day there—just me and my overpriced coffee—bonding over my terrible time management skills.

I signed up for a dance class to improve my coordination. During the first lesson, I tripped over my own feet and took half the class down with me. At least now I’m known as the dancer who ‘really knows how to make an entrance.’
My friend said I should drink more water for better health. So, I drank a gallon every hour, and now my biggest health concern is finding a bathroom every 10 minutes.
They told me to reduce screen time to improve my sleep. So, I threw out all my devices and now live in the woods. I don’t sleep any better, but at least the squirrels aren’t sending me work emails.
I heard eating vegetables is great for your skin. So, I blended 20 pounds of kale and carrots into a smoothie. Now my skin’s glowing… because I turned bright orange.
My teacher told me that practice makes perfect. So, I practiced playing guitar for 48 hours straight. Now I’m perfect… at being sleep-deprived and hallucinating song lyrics.
They said laughter is the best medicine, so I stopped taking all my actual medicine and now just laugh maniacally. The doctors aren’t impressed, but at least I’m committed to the bit.
I was told that walking 10,000 steps a day is good for my heart. So, I walked 100,000 steps in one day, and now my legs have filed a restraining order against me.
People say you should dress for the job you want. So, I showed up to work in a superhero costume. Turns out, they weren’t looking for a crime-fighting accountant.
They told me that sunscreen prevents aging, so I covered myself in SPF 1000 and haven’t left the shade in weeks. Now I’m not aging—I’m just becoming a mole person.
My financial advisor said I should save more for the future. So, I stopped buying food and started hoarding pennies. Now I have a solid retirement fund but no teeth left from malnutrition.

I read that multitasking is good for productivity. So, I’m currently brushing my teeth, answering emails, cooking dinner, and learning French. None of it is going well, but at least I’m impressively chaotic.
